{{distinguish|Mahar (tribe)|Mahaar}} {{other uses}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox ethnic group |image=Mahar.jpg |image_caption="A Mahar woman", a watercolour by [[M. V. Dhurandhar]], 1928 |regions=Major: [[Maharashtra]]
Minor: [[Madhya Pradesh]], [[Chhattisgarh]], [[Karnataka]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[West Bengal]], [[Gujarat]], [[Goa]] and other. |langs= [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Varhadi]], [[Konkani language|Konkani]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]] |rels= [[Buddhism]], [[Hinduism]], [[Sikhism]], [[Christianity]] }} The '''Mahar''' (also known as '''Maha''', '''Mehar''', '''Taral''', '''Dhegu Megu'''){{cite web |url=http://socialjustice.nic.in/UserView/index?mid=76750 |publisher=MSJE, Government of India |title=State wise list of Scheduled Castes updated up to 26-10-2017 |date=26 October 2017 |accessdate=2018-02-01}} is an [[India|Indian]] community found largely in the state of [[Maharashtra]], where they comprise 6% of the population, and neighbouring areas.{{cite book|author=Fred Clothey|title=Religion in India: A Historical Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7s376jMWBcEC&pg=PA213|year=2007|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-94023-8|page=213}} Most of the Mahar community followed [[B. R. Ambedkar]] in converting to [[Buddhism in India|Buddhism]] in the middle of the 20th century.{{cite book|last=Jaffrelot|first=Christophe|authorlink=Christophe Jaffrelot|title=Dr Ambedkar and Untouchability: Analysing and Fighting Caste|year=2005|publisher=Orient Blackswan Publisher|isbn=8178241560|pages=119‚Äì131|chapter=The ‚ÄòSolution‚Äô of Conversion}}{{cite book |editor-last=Smith |editor-first=Bardwell L. |title=Religion and the Legitimation of Power in South Asia |year=1978 |publisher=Brill |location=Leiden |isbn=9004056742 |pages=88‚Äì90 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x2Jzn_LuLasC&pg=PA88 |first=Eleanor |last=Zelliot |authorlink=Eleanor Zelliot |chapter=Religion and Legitimation in the Mahar Movement}} {{As of|2017}}, the Mahar caste was designated as a [[Scheduled Caste]] in 16 Indian states. ==History== The Mahar caste were considered an [[Untouchability|Untouchable]] community by the Hindu castes. However, they were socio-economically well above most other untouchable groups because their traditional role had been important in the village administrative system, had necessitated that they had at least a rudimentary education and frequently brought them into contact with upper-caste Hindus.{{cite journal |title=Understanding the Marathwada Riots: A Repudiation of Eclectic Marxism |first=Dipankar |last=Gupta |journal=Social Scientist |volume=7 |issue=10 |date=May 1979 |pages=3‚Äì22 |jstor=3516774 |subscription=yes}} They lived on the outskirts of villages and their duties included those of village watchman and trackers of thieves, messenger, wall mender, adjudicator of boundary disputes, street sweeper, supplying coarse cloth to the village and removers and processors of carcasses. In return for these services, the village granted them a [[Vatandar|watan]], or rights to small piece of land, to do their own cultivation. The watan also included share of village produce.{{cite book |editor-last=Kosambi |editor-first=Meera |last=Kulkarni |first=A. R. |chapter=The Mahar Watan: A Historical Perspective |title=Intersections: Socio-Cultural Trends in Maharashtra|date=2000|publisher=Sangam|location=London|isbn=978-0863118241|pages=121‚Äì140|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XU8dmAiaZSgC&pg=PA121|accessdate=2016-12-13}} They also worked at times as agricultural labourers.[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9050103/Mahar#285104.hook Britannica Online: Mahar]. Britannica.com. Retrieved on 2012-03-28.{{cite book|last1=Mendelsohn|first1=Oliver|last2=Vicziany|first2=Marika|authorlink2=Marika Vicziany|title=The untouchables : subordination, poverty and the state in modern India|date=1998|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge [u.a.]|isbn=0521553628|page=91|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FGbp9MjhvKAC&pg=PR10}}{{cite book|editor-first=Knut A.|editor-last=Jacobsen |title=Routledge Handbook of Contemporary India|date=2015|publisher=Routledge|location=New York, New York, USA|isbn=978-0415738651|pages=362‚Äì363|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=--9WCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA275 |accessdate=2016-10-25}} ===Pre-colonial period=== During the [[Bhakti]] era of Hinduism several Mahar saints such as [[Chokhamela]], [[Karmamela]], [[Sant Banka|Banka]], [[Sant Nirmala|Nirmala]]., [[Sant Soyarabai|Soyarabai]] and [[Bhagu]] became popular.{{cite book|first1=Anna S. |last1=King|first2=J. L. |last2=Brockington|title=The Intimate Other: Love Divine in Indic Religions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WhgDL6SwGeQC&pg=PA5|year=2005|publisher=Orient Blackswan|isbn=978-81-250-2801-7|pages=5‚Äì}}{{cite book|last=Stewart-Wallace|first=editorial advisers Swami Ghananda, Sir John|title=Women saints, east & west|year=1979|publisher=Vedanta|location=Hollywood, Calif.|isbn=0874810361|pages=61|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6IhLSGtuW_EC&pg=PA62}}{{cite book|last=Mikael|first=edited by Aktor, |title=From Stigma to Assertion : Untouchability, Identity & Politics in Early & Modern India|year=2008|publisher=Museum Tusculanum Press |location=Copenhagen|isbn=8763507757 |page=86 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zmKAqAQpIfwC&pg=PA86}} The Mahar were subjected to degradation during the rule of the [[Peshwa]]s, who treated them as untouchables.{{cite book|editor-last=Joshi|editor-first=Barbara R.|title=Untouchable! Voices of the Dalit Liberation Movement|year=1986|publisher=The Minority Rights Group|location=London|isbn=0862324602|pages=15‚Äì17|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y9CUItMT1zQC&pg=PA16|accessdate=2013-07-16|chapter=Roots of Revolt}} Specifically, they had to walk with a broom tied to their loincloth to wipe off their foot prints and an earthenware pot tied to their neck so their spit could not fall on the ground thereby polluting the road for hindus. Human sacrifices of the Mahars were common.{{Citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=October 2018}} For example, they could be buried alive under building foundations of Hindus. They were not allowed to move in public places in the mornings or evenings as their long shadows could defile caste hindus.They were not allowed to read and write. According to Mukta Salve, a fourteen year old [[Mang (caste)|Mang]] girl educated by [[Jyotirao Phule]] in the 1850s, passing the Talimkhana (local gymnasium) by a Mahar often resulted in his or her head being cut off and literally played with.Those resisting any sanctions could be trampled under an elephant on the grounds of the Peshwa's palace.{{cite book|title=Ambedkar and Buddhism|date=1 January 2006|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e-b2EzNRxQIC&pg=PA43|page=43|author=[[Sangharakshita]]}}{{cite book|title=Sites of Imperial Memory: Commemorating Colonial Rule in the Nineteenth and Twentieth centuries (Studies in Imperialism MUP)|editor1=Dominik Geppert|editor2=Frank Lorenz M√ºller|page=64,65|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CTChDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT64#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=Manchester University Press|year=2016}}{{Better source|reason=Can Mukta Salve, a Mang girl born decades after the end of Peshwa rule be regarded as a reliable source about the Mahars or her own community? |date=October 2018}} ===British India=== [[File:The tribes and castes of the Central Provinces of India (1916) (14740799376).jpg|thumb|right|A Mahar Man winding thread from ''The Tribes and Castes of the Central Provinces of India'' (1916)]] Under British rule, the Mahars became aware of the scope for social and political advancement Their traditional role had been low-status but important in the village system. A number of Mahars joined the army during the early British era. In 1873, [[Jyotirao Phule]], the founder of [[Satyashodhak Samaj]]{{mdash}}which aimed to abolish religious slavery from the influence of Brahaminical scriptures{{mdash}}organised Mahars. Their first conference was held in Mumbai in 1903.{{cite book|first1=Mikael|last1=Aktor |first2=Robert |last2=Deli√®ge|title=From Stigma to Assertion : Untouchability, Identity & Politics in Early & Modern India|year=2008|publisher=Museum Tusculanum Press|location=Copenhagen|isbn=8763507757|page=103|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zmKAqAQpIfwC&pg=PA103}}{{cite book|last=Keer|first=Dhananjay|title=Mahatma Jotirao Phooley : father of the Indian social revolution.|year=1997|publisher=Popular Prakashan|location=Bombay|isbn=817154066X|pages=126‚Äì127|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PFY9fz68KEsC&pg=PA229|edition=New}} Mahars were not allowed to enter Hindu temples and were considered [[Ritual purification|unclean]]. Even their entry into the shrines of Hindu gods was restricted.{{cite book|last=Galanter|first=Marc|title=South Asian politics and religion|year=1966|publisher=Princeton University Press|page=283|url=http://marcgalanter.net/Documents/thereligiousaspectsofcaste.pdf|editor-last=Smith |editor-first=D. E.}} In the 20th century, significant numbers left their traditional villages and moved into the urban centres of India in search of better employment and educational opportunities. They gave up their traditional jobs in cities, and to a large extent in rural Maharashtra, and took employment in the mills, docks, construction sites and railways.{{cite journal|last=Gandhi|first=Raj S.|title=From Caste to Class in Indian Society|journal=Humboldt Journal of Social Relations|date=Spring‚ÄìSummer 1980|volume=7|issue=2|pages=1‚Äì14|jstor=23261720|subscription=yes}} They created a receptive body of urban workers who were ready to join a political movement for higher status and equality.{{cite book |editor-last=Smith |editor-first=Bardwell L. |title=Religion and the Legitimation of Power in South Asia |year=1978 |publisher=Brill |location=Leiden |isbn=9004056742 |pages=90‚Äì92 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x2Jzn_LuLasC&pg=PA88 |first=Eleanor |last=Zelliot |authorlink=Eleanor Zelliot |chapter=Religion and Legitimation in the Mahar Movement}} ==Military role== The Mahar served in various armies over several centuries. The [[Maratha]] king [[Shivaji]] recruited a number of them into his army in the 17th century.Richard B. White [https://web.archive.org/web/20051102115844/http://asnic.utexas.edu/asnic/sagar/spring.1994/richard.white.art.html The Mahar Movement's Military Component]. utexas.edu They served as guards in hill forts and as soldiers.{{cite book|last=edited Shinoda|first=Takashi|title=The other Gujarat|year=2002|publisher=Popular Prakashan|location=Mumbai|isbn=8171548741|page=4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KZNfS7mikMoC&pg=PA1|author2=Shinoda, compiled by Takashi}} During the colonial period, large numbers of Mahars were recruited for military duties by the [[British East India Company|East India Company]] and the [[British Raj]]. The [[Battle of Koregaon]] (1 January 1818) is commemorated by an obelisk known as the Koregaon pillar{{mdash}}which was erected at the site of the battle{{mdash}}and by a medal issued in 1851. The pillar featured on the Mahar Regiment crest until the [[Independence of India]]; it is inscribed with the names of 22 Mahars killed at the battle.{{Cite journal |last =Kumbhojkar |first=Shraddha |authorlink= |title=Contesting Power, Contesting Memories - The History of the Koregaon Memorial |journal=The Economic and Political Weekly |publisher=EPW |year=2012 |url=http://www.epw.in/special-articles/contesting-power-contesting-memories.html |accessdate=2013-06-11}} The Mahar were initially heavily recruited into the East India company military units, but this process slowed after the [[Indian Rebellion of 1857]]. Their recruitment was halted under [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]] in the early 1890s. Before the rebellion, Mahar regiments made up one-sixth of the Bombay units of the East India Company but thereafter they were pensioned off and gradually removed from military service.{{cite book|last=Jaffrelot|first=Christophe|authorlink=Christophe Jaffrelot|title=Dr. Ambedkar and untouchability : fighting the Indian caste system|year=2005|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|isbn=0231136021|chapter=Ambedkar: Son of Mahar Soldier}}{{cite book|last=Rao|first=Anupama|title=The Caste Question: Dalits and the Politics of Modern India|year=2009|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, CA|isbn=0520257618|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tDRiJ3HZVPQC&pg=PA30}} Mahar recruitment reached its nadir in the early 1890s (sources differ as to exact year) when Kitchener halted the recruitment of Untouchables in Maharashtra in favour of "[[martial races]]," such as the Marathas and other north-western communities.{{cite book|last=Kamble|first=N. D.|title=Deprived castes and their struggle for equality|year=1983|publisher=Ashish Publisher House|pages=129‚Äì132}} The Mahar community attempted to confront this block with a petition circulated among the Mahar, [[Chamar]], and [[Mang (caste)|Mang]] former soldiers{{mdash}}all Marathi-speaking Untouchables{{mdash}}but the movement was unable to organise and submit their petition. The attempt at a challenge had been spearheaded by [[Gopal Baba Walangkar]], himself a Mahar and former soldier, but he found that Mahar military pensioners were unwilling to sign because they feared that they might lose their pensions.{{cite book |title=Dalits: Past, present and future |first=Anand |last=Teltumbde |publisher=Routledge |year=2016 |isbn=978-1-31552-643-0 |page=53 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fZXgDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT53}} In 1941, the [[Mahar Regiment]] was formed.[http://mod.nic.in/samachar/html/ch2.htm Mahars Turn Sixty]. |isbn=8189013017 |page=139 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Msaki69NQHsC&pg=PA139}} ===Buddhism=== The Christian conversion movement became overshadowed by the emergence of B. R. Ambedkar's Buddhist equivalent.{{cite book|last=Stackhouse|first=editors, Lalsangkima Pachuau, Max L.|title=News of boundless riches : interrogating, comparing, and reconstructing mission in a global era |year=2007 |publisher=ISPCK |location=Delhi |isbn=8184580134 |pages=230‚Äì232 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6OPJ1BJCLw8C&pg=PA229}} When he converted to Buddhism at [[Nagpur]] in 1956, many Mahars were among those of his followers who chose to do the same.{{cite web| last=Pritchett| first=Frances|url=http://www.columbia.edu/itc/mealac/pritchett/00ambedkar/timeline/1950s.html| title=In the 1950s| format=PHP| accessdate=2006-08-02}} As Buddhists, they gave up their traditional Hindu occupations and sought to redefine their social status.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} Ambedkar died about two months after this mass conversion.{{cite web|last=Gautam|first=C|title=Life of Babasaheb Ambedkar|url=http://www.ambedkar.org/Babasaheb/lifeofbabasaheb.htm|publisher=Ambedkar Memorial Trust, London|accessdate=2013-06-14}} At the same spot, after his cremation, more Mahars were converted to Buddhism.{{cite book |first=Detlef |last=Kantowsky |title= Buddhists in India today:descriptions, pictures, and documents|year= 2003 |publisher=Manohar Publishers & Distributors}} Now, this community is the third most populous in Mumbai. Some Buddhist leaders among the population prefer that the term ''Mahar'' no longer be applied to these converts.{{cite news |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/story/245413.html |title=Maya under fire from Dalit leaders in Maharashtra |work=Indian Express |date=1 December 2007 |accessdate=2012-03-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103184518/http://www.indianexpress.com/story/245413.html |archivedate=2008-01-03}} Buddhism appealed to the sense of equality in the Mahar;{{cite journal|last=Pandey|first=Gyanendra|title=The Time of the Dalit Conversion|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|date=6‚Äì12 May 2006|volume=41|issue=18|pages=1779+1781‚Äì1788|jstor=4418177}} an intellectual of Mahar origin said, "I have accepted Buddhist doctrine. I am Buddhist now. I am not Mahar now, not untouchable nor even Hindu. I have become a human being".{{cite book |last=Jaffrelot |first=Christophe |authorlink=Christophe Jaffrelot |year=2005 |title=The ‚Äòsolution‚Äô of conversion': Dr Ambedkar and Untouchability: Analysing and Fighting Caste |publisher=Orient Blackswan |page=138 |isbn=978-8-17824-156-2}} ==Dalit literature== According to [[Eleanor Zelliot]], Dalit literature originated in Marathi-speaking areas of [[Maharashtra]]. She credits Ambedkar, a Mahar himself, for inspiring many Dalit writers. [[Baburao Bagul]] (1930‚Äì2008), Shankarrao Kharat, and Bandhu Madhav were early Marathi writers from the Mahar community.{{cite book|editor-last1=Kachru|editor-first1=Braj B. |editor-last2=Kachru|editor-first2=Yamuna |editor-last3=Sridhar|editor-first3=S. N.|last=Zelliot|first=Eleanor |authorlink=Eleanor Zelliot |title=Language in South Asia, Part 9 |chapter=Dalit Literature, Language and Identity |year=2007 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |isbn=978-0-52178-141-1 |pages=450‚Äì454 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=O2n4sFGDEMYC&pg=PA451}} The Mahar writer [[Namdeo Dhasal]] (who founded [[Dalit Panther]]) was significant in the Dalit movement.{{cite news |title=Of art, identity, and politics |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/01/23/stories/2003012300470200.htm|publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=23 January 2003 }} Other notable Mahar authors writing in Marathi include [[Shantabai Kamble]], [[Raja Dhale]], [[Daya Pawar]], and [[Narendra Jadhav]].{{cite book|last1=Jadhav|first1=Narendra|title=Untouchables : my family's triumphant escape from India's caste system|date=2005|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, Calif.|isbn=978-0520252639|pages=53‚Äì54|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nuU0pc_D-qwC&pg=PA1|accessdate=2017-01-04}} ==See also== * [[Marathi Buddhists]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{notelist}} {{Infobox saint |name=Bl. Michelina of Pesaro, T.O.S.F. |birth_date=1300 |death_date=19 June 1356 |feast_day=June 20 |venerated_in=[[Roman Catholic Church]] |image=Federico barocci, beata michelina 1.jpg |imagesize= |caption=Michelina of Pesaro by [[Federico Barocci]] |birth_place=[[Pesaro]], [[Urbino]], [[Italy]] |death_place=[[Pesaro]], [[Urbino]], [[Italy]] |titles= |beatified_date=13 April 1737 |beatified_place= |beatified_by=[[Pope Clement XII]] |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes=Widow, Pilgrim and Franciscan [[Third Order|tertiary]] |patronage=widows; against mental illness; against death of children |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= }} '''Blessed Michelina of Pesaro, [[Third Order of St. Francis|T.O.S.F.]]''', (1300 - 1356) was an [[Italian people|Italian]] [[Roman Catholic]] [[Third Order of Saint Francis|Franciscan]] [[tertiary]] who was later [[beatification|beatified]].
== Biography ==
Michelina Metelli was born in [[Pesaro]], [[Italy]], to a wealthy Italian family. She married into the noble [[House of Malatesta|Malatesta family]] at the age of 12 and was widowed by age 20. She led a lifestyle of parties and luxury but, after the death of her only son, she experienced a vision of him in heaven, and decided to become a [[Franciscan]] [[penitent]].
She proceeded to give away all her belongings and property, and founded the [[Confraternity]] of the [[Annunciation]] to care for the poor, nurse the sick and bury the dead. Initially her family believed her to be insane and had her locked up. Upon her release from confinement, she made a [[pilgrimage]] to the [[Holy Land]] as [[penance]] for her sins. It is believed that she received the [[Stigmata]] in the course of this journey.
Michelina died at her home in Pesaro on 19 June 1356 of natural causes.
== Beatification == She was [[beatified]] on 13 April 1737 by [[Pope Clement XII]].
== References == *[http://www.therealpresence.org/eucharst/misc/Angels_Demons/ANGES_pesaro.pdf Blessed Michelina (Metelli Malatesta) of Pesaro] *[http://saints.sqpn.com/blessed-michelina-of-pesaro/ Blessed Michelina of Pesaro]

[[File:Museu arqueologic de Creta24.jpg|thumb|right|450px|Minoan Snake Goddess figurines, c 1600 BCE, Archaeological Museum, [[Heraklion]], Crete]]
'''"Snake goddess"''' is a type of [[figurine]] depicting a woman holding a snake in each hand, as were found in [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] archaeological sites in [[Crete]]. The first two of such figurines (both incomplete) were found by the British archaeologist [[Arthur Evans]] and date to the [[neo-palatial period]] of [[Minoan civilization]], c. 1700‚Äì1450 BCE. It was Evans who called the larger of his pair of figurines a "Snake Goddess", the smaller a "Snake Priestess"; since then, it has been debated whether Evans was right, or whether both figurines depict priestesses, or both depict the same deity or distinct deities.<ref name="drakon">{{Cite book |title=Drakon: Dragon Myth and Serpent Cult in the Greek and Roman Worlds |first=Daniel |last=Ogden |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2013 |pages=7‚Äì9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FQ2pAK9luwkC&pg=PA7}}</ref>
The figurines were found only in house sanctuaries, where the figurine appears as "the goddess of the household", and they are probably (according to [[Walter Burkert|Burkert]]) related to the [[Paleolithic]] traditions regarding women and domesticity.<ref name=Burkert23>Walter Burkert (1985). ''Greek Religion''. Harvard University Press. pp.23,30 {{ISBN|0-674-36281-0}}</ref> The figurines have also been interpreted as showing a [[Potnia Theron|mistress of animals]]-type goddess and as a precursor to [[Athena Parthenos]], who is also associated with snakes.{{r|drakon}}
==Figurines== [[File:ŒòŒµŒ¨ œÑœâŒΩ ŒåœÜŒµœâŒΩ 6393.JPG|thumb|The younger "snake goddess", from the palace of [[Knossos]]. [[Heraklion]] Archaeological Museum]]
The first two snake goddess figurines to be discovered were found by [[Arthur Evans]] in 1903, in the temple repositories of [[Knossos]].<ref>Bonney, Emily M. "Disarming the Snake Goddess: a Reconsideration of the Faience Figurines from the Temple Repositories at Knossos." ''Journal of Mediterranean Archaeology'', 24.2 (2011): 171-190.</ref> The figurines are made of [[Egyptian faience|faience]], a technique for glazing earthenware and other ceramic vessels by using a quartz paste. After firing, this produces bright colors and a lustrous sheen. This material symbolized the renewal of life in old [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]], therefore it was used in the funeral cult and in the sanctuaries.
These two figurines are today exhibited at the [[Herakleion Archeological Museum]] in Crete. It is possible that they illustrate the fashion of dress of Minoan women: a tight bodice which left the breasts bare, a long flounced skirt, and an apron made of material with embroidered or woven decoration. The larger of these figures has snakes crawling over her arms up to her [[tiara]]. The smaller figure holds two snakes in her raised hands, which seems to be the imitation of a [[Panthera|panther]].<ref>F. Schachermeyer. ''Die Minoische Kultur des alten Kreta''. W. Kohlhammer Verlag, Stuttgart 1964, p. 143.</ref> These were usually symbols of an [[earth goddess]].
In particular, one of the "snake goddesses" was found in a few scattered pieces, and was later filled with a solution of paraffin to preserve it from further damage.<ref name=MusartsBoston>L. D. C. "A Statuette of the Minoan Snake Goddess. Gift of Mrs. W. Scott Fitz." ''Museum of Fine Arts Bulletin'', Vol. 12, No. 73 (Dec., 1914), pp. 51‚Äì55 ([https://www.jstor.org/stable/4423650 online]).</ref> The goddess is depicted just as in other statues (crown on head, hands grasping snakes etc.). The expression on her face is described as lifelike, and is also wearing the typical Minoan dress. Another figure found in Berlin, made of bronze, looks more like a snake charmer with the snakes on top of her head. Many Minoan statues and statuettes seem to express a pride.<ref name=MusartsBoston/>
Clay sculptures with raised hands and curling snakes were found in the "House of the double axes" in [[Knossos]], in [[Asine]], in [[Gournia]], and in [[Myrtos]]. Objects with snakes curling up the sides of clay tubes were also found in [[Cyprus]] and [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]]. <ref name=Burkert23/>
==Interpretations== [[File:TempleRepositories.jpg|thumb|left|280px|Objects from the temple repositories ([[Knossos]]) after its discovery in 1903]]
The snake goddess's [[Minoan language|Minoan]] name may be related with ''A-sa-sa-ra'', a possible interpretation of inscriptions found in [[Linear A]] texts.<ref>Harald Haarmann: ''Das R√§tsel der [[Vinƒça culture|Donauzivilisation]]. Die Entdeckung der √§ltesten Hochkultur Europas'', Verlag C. H. Beck, [[Munich]], 2011, p. 241, {{ISBN|978-3-406-62210-6}}.</ref> Although Linear A is not yet deciphered, Palmer relates tentatively the inscription ''a-sa-sa-ra-me'' which seems to have accompanied goddesses, with the Hittite ''i≈°ha≈°≈°ara'', which means "mistress". <ref>F. Schachermeyer: ''Die Minoische Kultur des alten Kreta'', W.Kohlhammer, Stuttgart 1964, pp. 256, 263.</ref>
[[File:Snake-witch.JPG|thumb|right|upright|A woman (probably a goddess) holding snakes in both hands, from [[Gotland]], Sweden]]
The [[Serpent (symbolism)|serpent]] is often symbolically associated with the renewal of life because it sheds its skin periodically. A similar belief existed in the ancient [[Mesopotamian]]s and [[Semitic people|Semites]], and appears also in [[Hindu mythology]].<ref name=Columbia>[http://columbia.thefreedictionary.com/snake+worship ''Columbia. The free Dictionary'']</ref> The [[Pelasgian]] myth of creation refers to snakes as the reborn dead. However, [[Martin P. Nilsson]] noticed that in the Minoan religion the snake was the protector of the house,<ref name=Burkert23/> as it later appears also in [[Ancient Greek religion|Greek religion]].<ref>[[Zeus]] Kresios in the guise of a snake is regarded the "protector of storehouses". A snake is the "good daemon" at the temple of [[Athena]] on Acropolis, etc.: Martin Nilsson: ''Die Geschichte der griechischen Religion ''. Vol. 1. C. H. Beck Verlag, Munich 1967.</ref> Among the Greek [[Dionysos|Dionysiac]] cult it signified wisdom and was the symbol of fertility.<ref name=Columbia/>
Barry Powell suggested that the "snake goddess" reduced in legend into a folklore heroine was [[Ariadne]] (whose name might mean "utterly pure" or "the very holy one"), who is often depicted surrounded by [[Maenads]] and [[satyrs]].<ref>Barry Powell. ''Classical Myth'', with new translations of ancient texts by Herbert M. Howe. Prentice Hall Inc., Upper Saddle River (New Jersey) 1998, p. 368.</ref> Some scholars relate the snake goddess with the [[Phoenicia]]n [[Astarte]] (''virgin daughter''). She was the goddess of fertility and sexuality and her worship was connected with an orgiastic cult. Her temples were decorated with serpentine motifs. In a related Greek myth [[Europa (mythology)|Europa]], who is sometimes identified with Astarte in ancient sources, was a Phoenician princess whom [[Zeus]] abducted and carried to Crete.<ref name=Wunderlich260>H. G. Wunderlich: ''The secret of Crete''. Efstathiadis group S.A., 1994, pp. 260, 276, {{ISBN|960-226-261-3}} (First British edition, published 1975 by Souvenir Press Ltd., London).</ref><ref>[[Lucian of Samosata]] (200 AD): ''[[De Dea Syria]]'' 4.</ref> Evans tentatively linked the snake goddess with the Egyptian snake goddess [[Wadjet]] but did not pursue this connection. Statuettes similar to the "snake goddess" type identified as "priest of Wadjet" and "magician" were found in Egypt.<ref>Cristopher L. C. E. Whitcombe: ''Minoan Snake Goddess". 8: Snakes, Egypt, Magic and women (external links).</ref>
==Sacral knot== Both goddesses have a knot with a projecting looped cord between their breasts. Evans noticed that these are analogous to the ''sacral knot'', his name for a knot with a loop of fabric above and sometimes fringed ends hanging down below. Numerous such symbols in ivory, faience, painted in frescoes or engraved in seals sometimes combined with the symbol of the double-edged axe or [[labrys]] which was the most important [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] religious symbol.<ref>F. Schachermeyer: ''Die minoische Kultur des alten Kreta''. W. Kohlhammer Verlag, Stuttgart 1964, pp. 161, 163.</ref> Such symbols were found in [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] and [[Mycenaean Greece|Mycenaean]] sites. It is believed that the ''sacral knot'' was the symbol of holiness on human figures or cult-objects.<ref>F. Schachermeyer: ''Die Minoische Kultur des alten Kreta''. W. Kohlhammer Verlag, Stuttgart 1964, p. 163 f.</ref> Its combination with the double-axe can be compared with the Egyptian [[ankh]] (eternal life), or with the [[tyet]] (welfare/life) a symbol of [[Isis]] (the knot of Isis).<ref>Cristopher L. C. E. Whitkombe: ''Minoan snake goddess''. 9: Snake charmers (external links).</ref>
==Oracle== Wadjet had a famous [[oracle]] in the city [[Per-Wadjet]] (Greek name [[Buto]]). According to [[Herodotus]] this may have been the source of the oracular tradition which spread to Greece from Egypt.<ref>Herodotus.''Histories'' II, 55, and VII, 134.</ref> The serpents were considered the protectors of the temples and the chthonic masters of the ancient [[earth goddess]]. In Greece the old oracles were devoted to the [[mother goddess]].
==Comparison to other goddesses== Other goddesses probably associated with the "snake goddess" are: * The ancient Egyptian goddess [[Renenutet]], who often appeared in the form of a hooded cobra.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} * The Phoenician goddess [[Tanit]], worshipped as a patron goddess of [[Carthage]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} * The Indian snake goddess [[Manasa]], literally meaning "of the mind", or "conceived in the mind", or "power of the mind" is the [[tutelary deity]] of snakes and fertility, worshipped mainly in [[Bengal]] and the eastern parts of India. * [[Diktynna]], also known as the Cretan "Mistress of the Wild", is a possible variant.{{Citation needed|date=September 2013}}
==Art== The feminist artwork ''[[The Dinner Party]]'' by [[Judy Chicago]] features a place setting for a "Snake Goddess".<ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/place_settings Place Settings]. Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved on 2015-08-06.</ref>
==See also== *[[Ariadne]] *[[Astarte]] *[[Ishtar]] *[[Gorgon]] (female monsters with sharp fangs and hair of living, venomous snakes in Greek mythology) *[[Matriarchal religion]] *[[Potnia theron]] *[[Wadjet]] *[[Snake-witch stone]], a picture stone from Gotland popularly called ''ormgudinna'' *[[Snake worship]] (in Hindu mythology)
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{Commons category|Snake Goddess}} * [http://witcombe.sbc.edu/snakegoddess/ Minoan Snake Goddess] essay by Christopher L. C. E. Witcombe originally in ''Images Of Women In Ancient Art'' - Accessed July 2006 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080913010633/http://www.gotmus.i.se/1engelska/bildstenar/engelska/nar.htm The Picture Stone from Smiss at N√§r], Historical museum of Gotland

{{Drugbox | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = | IUPAC_name = ''N''-(2-Methoxybenzyl)-2-(3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl)ethan-1-amine | image = NBOMe-mescaline-molecule.png <!--Clinical data--> | legal_AU = | legal_CA = | legal_UK = | legal_US = unscheduled | routes_of_administration = [[Wiktionary:oral|Oral]], intranasal, bucal, [[sublingual]], [[intravenous]] <!--Pharmacokinetic data--> | elimination_half-life = ? <!--Identifiers--> | CAS_number_Ref = {{cascite|correct|??}} | CAS_number = 1354632-01-1 | ATC_prefix = none | PubChem = 57501069 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 25949200 <!--Chemical data--> | C=19 | H=25 | N=1 | O=4 | molecular_weight = 331.4061 g/mol | smiles = COC1=CC(CCNCC2=C(OC)C=CC=C2)=CC(OC)=C1OC.Cl | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C19H25NO4/c1-21-16-8-6-5-7-15(16)13-20-10-9-14-11-17(22-2)19(24-4)18(12-14)23-3/h5-8,11-12,20H,9-10,13H2,1-4H3 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = USPSMWCGHVXKMN-UHFFFAOYSA-N | synonyms = mescaline-NBOMe; 345-NBOMe; N-(2-methoxybenzyl)-3,4,5-trimethoxyphenethylamine; 2-(3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl)-N-[(2-methoxyphenyl)methyl]ethanamine; 3,4,5-Trimethoxy-N-(2-methoxybenzyl)phenethylamine | melting_point = <!--?--> | boiling_point = <!--?--> }} '''NBOMe-mescaline''' or '''mescaline-NBOMe''' is a synthetic [[phenethylamine|substituted phenethylamine]]. It is a partial agonist of serotonin receptors with a [[5-HT2A receptor|5-HT<sub>2A</sub>]] pKi originally reported as 7.3 (i.e. Ki of approximately 50nM),<ref name="NS 1999">{{cite journal |title=N-Benzylated derivatives of the hallucinogenic drugs mescaline and escaline as partial agonists at rat vascular 5-HT2A receptors |url=http://bitnest.ca/external.php?id=%2502%257F%2505J%2516%251A%2509%2504%2504e%255C%25258%2522UV%2508%2507N%2501Q%2540i%251Ec%250B7kq |journal=Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Archives of Pharmacology |date=1999-01-01 |volume=359 |issue=<!--suppl. 3?--> |pages=R29 |first=HH |last=Pertz |first2=A |last2=Rheineck |first3=S |last3=Elz}}</ref> though more modern techniques assayed it as 140nM at 5-HT<sub>2A</sub> and 640nM at 5-HT<sub>2C</sub>, making it one of the least potent compounds among the n-benzyl phenethylamines. <ref>Rickli A, Luethi D, Reinisch J, Buchy D, Hoener MC, Liechti ME. Receptor interaction profiles of novel N-2-methoxybenzyl (NBOMe) derivatives of 2,5-dimethoxy-substituted phenethylamines (2C drugs). ''Neuropharmacology''. 2015 Dec;99:546-53. {{PMID|26318099}} doi: 10.1016/j.neuropharm.2015.08.034</ref>
== History == NBOMe-mescaline and [[NBOMe-escaline]] were first reported in 1999 resulting from research performed at [[Free University of Berlin]] concerning their activity as partial agonists at rat vascular 5-HT2A receptors.<ref name="NS 1999">{{cite journal |title=N-Benzylated derivatives of the hallucinogenic drugs mescaline and escaline as partial agonists at rat vascular 5-HT2A receptors |url=http://bitnest.ca/external.php?id=%2502%257F%2505J%2516%251A%2509%2504%2504e%255C%25258%2522UV%2508%2507N%2501Q%2540i%251Ec%250B7kq |journal=Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Archives of Pharmacology |date=1999-01-01 |volume=359 |issue=<!--suppl. 3?--> |pages=R29 |first=HH |last=Pertz |first2=A |last2=Rheineck |first3=S |last3=Elz}}</ref> NBOMe-mescaline was first reported in September 2008 to have been self administered by humans as a [[psychedelic drug]] at some unspecified point prior.<ref name="bluelight 25B-NB">[https://www.bluelight.org/vb/threads/388351-25B-NB-%28n-Benzyl-2C-B%29 25B-NB (n-Benzyl-2C-B) @ BlueLight.org]</ref> It first became available as a commodity in the research chemical market in May 2010 several months after a few 25x-[[NBOMe]]s became available.
== Properties and chemistry ==
Solubility of the [[hydrochloride salt]]: ~5 mg/ml in Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS) @ [[pH]] 7.2; ~10 mg/ml in [[ethanol]] & [[Dimethylformamide|DMF]]; ~20 mg/ml in [[DMSO]].<ref name="MSDS">[https://www.caymanchem.com/msdss/9001990m.pdf Cayman Chemical's Mescaline NBOMe HCl MSDS]</ref>
=== Synthesis === NBOMe-mescaline can be synthesized from [[mescaline]] and 2-methoxybenzaldehyde, via reductive [[alkylation]]. That can be done stepwise by first making the [[imine]] and then reducing the formed imine with [[sodium borohydride]], or by direct reaction with [[sodium triacetoxyborohydride]]. An alternative production method which removes the need to obtain the illegal compound mescaline as an isolated precursor can be achieved via a [[one-pot reaction]] utilizing 3,4,5-trimethoxy[[phenylacetonitrile]] with [[Lithium Aluminium Hydride]] as a reducing agent.
== Psychedelic dosage in humans == There have been very few reports of human use of NBOMe-mescaline. [[Psychedelic drug|Psychedelic]] visual, auditory and mental effects start around 50 mg intranasally.<ref name="bluelight big">[https://www.bluelight.org/vb/threads/505420-The-Big-amp-Dandy-NBOMe-Mescaline-Thread The Big & Dandy NBOMe-Mescaline Thread @ BlueLight.org]</ref>
==Legal status== NBOMe-mescaline is not listed in the schedules set out by the [[United Nations]]' [[Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs]] from 1961 nor their [[Convention on Psychotropic Substances]] from 1971,<ref name="UNCPS">[https://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/commissions/CND/conventions.html UN International Drug Control Conventions]</ref> so the signatory countries to these international drug control treaties are not required by said treaties to control NBOMe-mescaline.
=== United States === NBOMe-mescaline is not listed in the [[List_of_Schedule_I_drugs_(US)|list of scheduled controlled substances]] in the USA.<ref name="PART 1308 ‚Äî SCHEDULES OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES - 1308.11 Schedule I">[http://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/21cfr/cfr/1308/1308_11.htm ¬ß1308.11 Schedule I.]</ref> It is therefore not [[Controlled Substances Act#Schedules of controlled substances|scheduled]] at the [[Federal government of the United States|federal level]] in the [[United States]], but it is possible that NBOMe-mescaline could legally be considered an [[Structural analog#Chemistry|analog]] of [[mescaline]], and therefore sales or [[Drug possession|possession]] could potentially be prosecuted under the [[Federal Analogue Act]].<ref>[https://www.erowid.org/psychoactives/law/analog/analog_info1.shtml Erowid Analog Law Vault : Federal Controlled Substance Analogue Act Summary]</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{N-benzylphenethylamine-Legality-United Kingdom}}

The '''''Oracle of the Lamb''''' is an [[Ancient Egyptian literature|ancient Egyptian]] prophetic text written on a [[papyrus]] in [[Demotic (Egyptian)|Demotic Egyptian]] and dated to the thirty-third year of the reign of the Roman Emperor [[Augustus]] (r. 27 BC ‚Äì 14 AD).<ref name="gozzoli 2006 293 294">Gozzoli (2006), pp. 293‚Äì294.</ref> In it, a lamb speaks and provides [[prophecies]] to a man named Pasenhor. The lamb describes a world turned upside-down and reduced to chaos: temples are in disarray, the ruler has now become the ruled, and the [[Medes]] (i.e. referring to the [[History of Persian Egypt|Persian domination of Egypt]]) have come to destroy Egypt.<ref name="gozzoli 2006 293 294"/> It also mentions that the [[Ancient Greece|Greeks]] (i.e. referring to the [[History of Ptolemaic Egypt|Ptolemaic domination of Egypt]]) will take the [[Hedjet|White Crown]] (representing pharaonic [[Upper Egypt]]).<ref name="gozzoli 2006 293 294"/> The story is comparable in style, tone, and subject matter to prophetic texts of the [[Middle Kingdom of Egypt]], such as the ''[[Prophecy of Neferti]]''.<ref>Gozzoli (2006), 301‚Äì302.</ref>
==See also==
* [[Demotic Chronicle]] * [[Oracle of the Potter]]

[[File:Agesilaus and Pharnabazus..gif|thumb|Agesilaus and Pharnabazus.]] '''Pharnabazus''' (died before 430 BCE), was a member of the [[Pharnacid dynasty]] that governed the province of [[Hellespontine Phrygia]] as [[satrap]]s for the [[Achaemenid Empire]].
He is a very obscure figure, almost always mentioned alongside his father [[Artabazos I of Phrygia|Artabazus]]. He may have succeeded his father as satrap between 455 and 430 BCE, but it is also possible that Artabazus was directly succeeded by his grandson (Pharnabazus' son), [[Pharnaces II of Phrygia|Pharnaces II]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pharnabazus 01}} [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:430s BC deaths]] [[Category:Achaemenid satraps of Phrygia]] [[Category:5th-century BC Iranian people]] [[Category:Pharnacid dynasty]]

{{Update|date=November 2017}} {{pp-pc1}} {{Infobox person | name = Rebecca Watson | image = Rebecca Watson NECSS 2011.jpg | alt = | caption = Watson in 2011 | birth_name = Rebecca Kay Watson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|10|18|mf=yes}} | birth_place = United States | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | alma mater = [[Boston University]] | other_names = ''The Skepchick'' | spouse = | relations = | years_active = 2005‚Äìpresent | notable_works = | known_for = Skeptical Rogue to [[Steven Novella]] on [[The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe]] podcast, [[science communication]], [[atheism]], [[feminism]] | influences = | influenced = | website = [http://skepchick.org/ skepchick.org] }}
'''Rebecca Kay Watson''' (born October 18, 1980) is an American [[blog]]ger and [[podcast]] host. She is the founder of the Skepchick blog and former co-host of ''[[The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe]]'' podcast. She also previously co-hosted the ''[[Little Atoms]]'' podcast.<ref name="brooklinetab1">{{cite journal| last = Simpson| first = Neal|date=September 2007| title = Blogger looks to take her war on pseudoscience to the airwaves| journal = Brookline TAB| url = http://www.wickedlocal.com/brookline/archive/x1429055418| archive-url = https://archive.is/20130209120521/http://www.wickedlocal.com/brookline/archive/x1429055418| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 2013-02-09| accessdate = 2008-10-30}}</ref><ref name="vue1">{{cite journal|last=Mouallem |first=Omar |authorlink = Omar Mouallem |date=August 2008 |title=Making a Living of Bullshit Detecting |journal=[[Vue Weekly]] |issue=671 |url=http://www.vueweekly.com/article.php?id=9429 |accessdate=2008-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912125609/http://www.vueweekly.com/article.php?id=9429 |archivedate=September 12, 2008 }}</ref>
==Career==
===Skepchick=== Watson founded Skepchick in 2005, describing it as "an organization dedicated to promoting skepticism and critical thinking among women around the world".<ref name="skepchick24nov">[https://web.archive.org/web/20051124160701/http://www.skepchick.org/index.html Skepchick.org November 24, 2005] at the Internet Archive Wayback Machine</ref> Originally the site consisted of a forum and a monthly online magazine, ''Skepchick Magazine'', which was launched January 15, 2006.<ref name="skepchick23dec">[https://web.archive.org/web/20051223110704/http://www.skepchick.org/ Skepchick.org December 23, 2005] at the Internet Archive Wayback Machine</ref>
In 2006, Watson released The Skepchick Calendar, a [[pin-up]] calendar featuring pictures of [[Philosophical skepticism|skeptical]] women for every month. Proceeds provided the attendance fee for several female applicants to attend the [[James Randi Educational Foundation|James Randi Educational Foundation's]] [[The Amaz!ng Meeting]].<ref name="skepchickcaldendar2006">{{cite web |url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2005/09/18/skepchicks/ |title=Skepchicks |accessdate=2010-01-22 |work= Bad Astronomy}}</ref>
On February 12, 2006, Watson created a blog titled ''Memoirs of a Skepchick'', as an addition to the magazine.<ref name="memoirs">[http://skepchick.org/2006/02/hello-world/ It‚Äôs snowing, so I started a blog.] first skepchick blog post</ref> Eventually the blog, now simply titled ''Skepchick'', became the main site, as Skepchick Magazine was discontinued in July 2006. Fourteen other bloggers beside Watson now contribute regularly, including one man.<ref name="profile">[http://skepchick.org/blog/?page_id=855/ Who's who on Skepchick] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906063430/http://skepchick.org/blog/?page_id=855%2F |date=September 6, 2008 }}</ref>
In 2010, Skepchick partnered with the Women Thinking Free Foundation to host a vaccination drive with the help of the "Hug Me!" campaign at the [[Dragon*Con]] convention in [[Atlanta, Georgia]].<ref name="skeptic-zone-2010">{{Cite podcast | number = 99 | last1 = Saunders | first1 = Richard | authorlink1 = Richard Saunders (skeptic) | last2 = Dunlop | authorlink2 = Rachael Dunlop | first2 = Rachael | last3 = Atkinson | first3 = Bill | title = The Skeptic Zone | time = 0:30:20 | url = http://skepticzone.libsyn.com/the-skeptic-zone-99-10-sep-2010 | accessdate = 2013-08-20 }}</ref> Public health staff allowed members of the public to receive a [[DPT vaccine|TDAP]] vaccination free of charge, as well as educational literature promoting immunization.<ref name="hugme">{{Cite web | title = Hug Me! I'm Vaccinated! | publisher = Women Thinking Free Foundation | accessdate = 2013-08-21 | url = http://hugmeimvaccinated.org/newsarchives.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130919031446/http://hugmeimvaccinated.org/newsarchives.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2013-09-19 }}</ref> In 2011, Skepchick, the [[James Randi Educational Foundation]] (JREF), and the Women Thinking Free Foundation partnered to offer a similar vaccination clinic at [[The Amaz!ng Meeting]] 9 in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]].<ref name="hugme" />
===The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe=== {{main|The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe}} Watson's first appearance on The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe podcast was on episode 33 (March 9, 2006), where she was interviewed about her work on Skepchick. She returned on episode 36 (March 29, 2006) as a regular member of the panel.<ref name="archive">[http://www.theskepticsguide.org/archive.asp The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe episode archive] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018180403/http://www.theskepticsguide.org/archive.asp |date=October 18, 2008 }}</ref> On December 27, 2014, she announced that she has recorded her final show prior to leaving the organization.<ref name="Why I Left SGU">{{cite web|last1=Watson|first1=Rebecca|title=Why I‚Äôve Left SGU|url=http://skepchick.org/2014/12/why-ive-left-sgu/|website=Skepchick|accessdate=31 December 2014}}</ref>
===The Public Radio Talent Quest=== In May 2007, Watson entered The Public Radio Talent Quest, a contest aimed to find new public radio hosts.<ref name="entry-quest">[http://skepchick.org/2007/05/a-very-special-audio-blog-posting-vote-for-me/ A very special audio blog posting. Vote for me!] - blog post announcing her first entry in the PRTQ</ref> The contest claims to have received more than 1,400 entries.<ref name="PRTQ">[http://www.publicradioquest.com/ Public Radio Talent Quest]</ref> Watson's entries won the popular vote in every round,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicradioquest.com/node/2640|title=PRX Announces Winners of Public Radio Talent Quest|date=2007-10-27|last=Watson|first=Rebecca|publisher=[[Public Radio Exchange|PRX]]|accessdate=2008-11-11}}</ref> and she was declared one of three winners who each would receive $10,000 to produce a public radio pilot.<ref name="talent">{{cite journal|last=Simon|first=Clea|date=January 2008|title=Showing a talent for radio|journal=[[The Boston Globe]]|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/articles/2008/01/11/showing_a_talent_for_radio/|accessdate=2008-10-30}}</ref>
Watson's pilot, ''Curiosity, Aroused'',<ref name="CA">{{cite web|url=http://curiosityaroused.wordpress.com/2007/12/16/hello-world/|title=Curiosity, Aroused: The Pilot|date=2007-12-16|last=Watson|first=Rebecca|publisher=[[WordPress]]|accessdate=2008-11-06}}</ref> was an hour-long program focused on science and skepticism.<ref name="talent" /> It featured interviews with [[Richard Saunders (skeptic)|Richard Saunders]] of Australian Skeptics and Mystery Investigators, and [[Richard Wiseman]], author of Quirkology and Professor of the Public Understanding of Psychology at the [[University of Hertfordshire]]. She also investigated claims of poisonous amounts of lead in lipstick, went on a ghost tour in [[Boston]] and visited a Psychic Fair.
Her show was the only one among the three winners not to receive funding by the [[Corporation for Public Broadcasting]] for being turned into a one-year show.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.publicradioquest.com/node/2710|title=Big News from PRX and CPB|date=2008-06-26|accessdate=2008-11-06}}</ref><ref name="WCRB">{{cite journal|last=Simon|first=Clea|date=July 2008|title=At WCRB, it's a grand old tradition|journal=[[The Boston Globe]]|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/articles/2008/07/03/at_wcrb_its_a_grand_old_tradition/|accessdate=2008-10-30}}</ref>
==Personal life== Watson grew up in [[New Jersey]] and earned a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in communications from [[Boston University]] in 2002.<ref name="april fool">{{cite web|last=Potash|first=Larry|title=Be skeptical or be an April fool|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-03-31/news/0603310344_1_fools-day-fool-s-errand-magician|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=August 24, 2013|date=March 31, 2006}}</ref><ref name="wicked local">{{cite web|last=Simpson |first=Neal |title=Blogger looks to take her war on pseudoscience to the airwaves |url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/brookline/fun/entertainment/x1429055418 |work=Wicked Local |accessdate=August 24, 2013 |date=September 27, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130905214418/http://www.wickedlocal.com/brookline/fun/entertainment/x1429055418 |archivedate=September 5, 2013 }}</ref> While attending Boston University, Watson worked as a magician.<ref name="Boston Phoenix">{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Georgiana|title=Not-so-sure guys|url=http://thephoenix.com/Boston/life/78548-not-so-sure-guys/|accessdate=August 24, 2013|newspaper=The Boston Phoenix|date=March 19, 2009}}</ref> Watson says she "had relatively little serious interest in science" during her high school and college years but became more interested in science after being a magician and meeting with people like [[James Randi]].<ref name="Skepchick 2011-09-29">{{cite web|author=Watson, Rebecca|title=Mom, don't read this|url=http://skepchick.org/2011/09/mom-dont-read-this/|work=skepchick.org|date=September 29, 2011|accessdate=August 24, 2013}}</ref><ref name=sc-congrats>{{cite web | url = http://skepchick.org/2009/07/congrats-becca-and-sid/ | title = Skepchick Congrats Becca and Sid|date=July 16, 2011 |website=Skepchick|author= bug_girl}}</ref> On July 11, 2009, she and Sid Rodrigues were married in a surprise ceremony during [[James Randi Educational Foundation#The Amaz!ng Meeting|The Amaz!ng Meeting 7]].<ref name=sc-congrats/> On April 8, 2011, she announced that she and Rodrigues were separated and seeking a divorce.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://skepchick.org/2011/04/a-note-about-my-personal-life/ | work=Skepchick |title=A Note About My Personal Life|date=April 8, 2011|first=Rebecca|last=Watson}}</ref>
==Elevator incident==<!-- linked from redirect [[Elevatorgate]] --> At the June 2011 World Atheist Convention, on a panel that also included [[Richard Dawkins]], Watson spoke about her experiences with sexism within the atheist movement. Among the topics in a [[vlog]] posted following her return from the trip, she described how after the talk around 4 am after leaving the hotel bar, a man from the group followed her into an elevator and said "Don't take this the wrong way, but I find you very interesting, and I would like to talk more. Would you like to come to my hotel room for coffee?" Watson cited various contextual reasons why this felt inappropriate, and advised, "guys, don't do that."<ref name="watsonreactiontoelevatorman">{{cite video | people = Rebecca Watson | date = 2011-06-20 | title = About Mythbusters, Robot Eyes, Feminism, and Jokes | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uKHwduG1Frk | format = YouTube | time = 5:06 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Watson|first=Rebecca|title=It Stands to Reason, Skeptics Can Be Sexist Too|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2012/10/sexism_in_the_skeptic_community_i_spoke_out_then_came_the_rape_threats.single.html|publisher=Slate|accessdate=26 October 2012|date=24 October 2012}}</ref> The ensuing discussion and criticism across several websites, including [[Reddit]] and the ''[[Pharyngula (blog)|Pharyngula]]'' blog, became highly polarized and heated to the point of name-calling and some personal threats, including rape and death threats.<ref name=milleraf>{{Citation |last= Miller |first= Ashley F. |title= The non-religious patriarchy: why losing religion HAS NOT meant losing white male dominance |journal= CrossCurrents |volume=63 |issue=2 |date=June 2013 |doi=10.1111/cros.12025 |pages=211‚Äì226 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Winston |first= Kimberly |title= Atheists address sexism issues |date= September 15, 2011 |work= USA Today |agency= Religion News Service |url= http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/religion/story/2011-09-15/atheist-sexism-women/50416454/1 |accessdate= August 6, 2013}}</ref>
The controversy increased when Richard Dawkins joined the blog discussion later in 2011, describing her response as an overreaction since a man had merely conversed with her, "politely". Dawkins contrasted the "elevator incident" with the plight of [[Women in Islam|women in Islamic countries]],<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303365804576431943681248906 | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=James | last=Taranto | authorlink = James Taranto | title=Commander in Tweet | date=July 7, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2011-09-02-dawkins-watson-and-the-elevator-ride/|title=Dawkins, Watson and the elevator ride|last=Reporter|first=Staff|work=The M&G Online|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/national/2011/07/richard-dawkins-draws-feminist-wrath-over-sexual-harassment-comments/39637/|title=Richard Dawkins Gets into a Comments War with Feminists|date=July 6, 2011|author=Cailtin Dickson|publisher=[[The Atlantic Wire]] }}</ref> in a post titled "Dear Muslima": {{quote|Dear Muslima
Stop whining, will you. Yes, yes, I know you had your genitals mutilated with a razor blade, and ... yawn ... .don't tell me yet again, I know you aren't allowed to drive a car, and you can't leave the house without a male relative, and your husband is allowed to beat you, and you'll be stoned to death if you commit adultery. But stop whining, will you. Think of the suffering your poor American sisters have to put up with. Only this week I heard of one, she calls herself Skep"chick", and do you know what happened to her? A man in a hotel elevator invited her back to his room for coffee. I am not exaggerating. He really did. He invited her back to his room for coffee. Of course she said no, and of course he didn't lay a finger on her, but even so... And you, Muslima, think you have misogyny to complain about! For goodness sake grow up, or at least grow a thicker skin.<ref name="privilege-delusion"/>}}
Dawkins received criticism for his remarks from [[David Allen Green]] for dismissing lesser wrongs because bigger wrongs exist, and by [[Remy Stern]] for spending so much time "arguing about a proposition in an elevator."<ref name="New Statesman">{{cite web|author1=David Allen Green| authorlink = David Allen Green| title=Sharing a lift with Richard Dawkins|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/david-allen-green/2011/07/richard-dawkins-chewing-gum|website=newstatesman.com|publisher=New Statesman|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=Gawker>{{cite web|author1=Remy Stern |title=Richard Dawkins Torn Limb From Limb‚ÄîBy Atheists |url=http://gawker.com/5818993/richard-dawkins-torn-limb-from-limbby-atheists |publisher=Gawker |accessdate=19 January 2015 |archivedate=19 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150119033423/http://gawker.com/5818993/richard-dawkins-torn-limb-from-limbby-atheists |df= }}</ref>
Dawkins further explained himself: {{quote|Here‚Äôs the argument I was making. The man in the elevator didn‚Äôt physically touch her, didn‚Äôt attempt to bar her way out of the elevator, didn‚Äôt even use foul language at her. He spoke some words to her. Just words. She no doubt replied with words. That was that. Words. Only words, and apparently quite polite words at that ... Muslim women suffer physically from misogyny, their lives are substantially damaged by religiously inspired misogyny. Not just words, real deeds, painful, physical deeds, physical privations, legally sanctioned demeanings.<ref name="Guard"/>}}
In response to Dawkins' comments, Watson stated that she would no longer buy or endorse his books and lectures,<ref name="privilege-delusion">{{Cite web|url=http://skepchick.org/2011/07/the-privilege-delusion|title=The Privilege Delusion|author=Rebecca Watson|date=July 5, 2011|publisher=Skepchick}}</ref> which was viewed<ref name="Dawkins-Torn-Limb">{{Cite web|url=http://gawker.com/5818993/richard-dawkins-torn-limb-from-limbby-atheists |title=Richard Dawkins Torn Limb From Limb‚ÄîBy Atheists |author=Remy Stern |date=July 7, 2011 |publisher=Gawker |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150119033423/http://gawker.com/5818993/richard-dawkins-torn-limb-from-limbby-atheists |archivedate=January 19, 2015 |df= }}</ref> as a boycott, writing:
{{quote|[Dawkins] therefore will no longer be rewarded with my money, my praise, or my attention. I will no longer recommend his books to others, buy them as presents, or buy them for my own library. I will not attend his lectures or recommend that others do the same. ... But those of us who are humanists and feminists will find new, better voices to promote and inspire, and Dawkins will be left alone to fight the terrible injustice of standing in elevators with gum-chewers.<ref name="privilege-delusion"/>}}
The result of this exchange led to an extended [[Flaming (Internet)|internet flame war]] that several reports dubbed "elevatorgate".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://synapses.co.za/elevatorgate-power-words/|title=Elevatorgate and the power of words|first=Jacques|last=Rousseau|publisher=Synapses|date=2011-07-14}}</ref><ref name="Guard">{{cite web|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2011-09-02-dawkins-watson-and-the-elevator-ride/|title=Dawkins, Watson and the elevator ride|publisher=Mail & Guardian|date=2011-09-02|accessdate=2018-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jul/24/richard-dawkins-women-chilly-climate|title=Rihard Dawkins, check the evidence on the 'chilly climate' for women|first=Emily|last=Band|publisher=The Guardian|date=2011-07-24|accessdate=2018-08-23}}</ref> In the wake of this and an incident at a [[Center for Inquiry]]-sponsored event, where female atheists reported gender bias and inappropriate behavior, organizations including the [[Richard Dawkins Foundation for Reason and Science|Richard Dawkins Foundation]] have reviewed their policies regarding sexual harassment and non-discrimination.<ref name="milleraf" /> In 2014, Richard Dawkins stated, "There should be no rivalry in victimhood, and I'm sorry I once said something similar to American women complaining of harassment, inviting them to contemplate the suffering of Muslim women by comparison", in response to which Watson tweeted, "Richard Dawkins just did the blog-equivalent of coughing into his hand while mumbling 'sorry' to me. Eh, I'll take it."<ref name=RDnet>{{cite web|title=Who is "belittling" what?|url=https://richarddawkins.net/2014/08/who-is-belittling-what/|website=richarddawkins.net|publisher=The Richard Dawkins Foundation for Reason and Science|accessdate=19 January 2015|date=6 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rebecca Watson, Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/rebeccawatson/status/497087309805027328|website=twitter.com|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref>
==Honors== An [[Asteroid group#The asteroid belt|outer main-belt]] [[asteroid]] discovered on March 22, 2001, by [[David H. Healy]] was named [[153289 Rebeccawatson]] in her honor.<ref name="asteroid">[http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=153289 153289 Rebeccawatson] at the JPL Small-Body Database Browser</ref>

{{Infobox church | denomination = [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] | name = {{lang|it|Santuario della Madonna del Divino Amore}} | other name = Shrine of Our Lady of Divine Love | image = Divino Amore - prospetto 1220625.JPG | caption = Shrine of Our Lady of Divine Love | coordinates = {{coord|41|46|43.5|N|12|32|37.9|E|type:landmark_region:IT|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Via Ardeatina]],
[[Rome]], Italy | website = {{URL|http://www.santuariodivinoamore.it/ }} | status = [[Parish church]], Shrine, One of the [[Seven Pilgrim Churches of Rome]] | architectural type = [[Church (building)|Church]] | diocese = [[Diocese of Rome]] }} '''Santuario della Madonna del Divino Amore''' or the shrine of Our Lady of Divine Love is a [[Roman Catholic]] shrine dedicated to the [[Blessed Virgin Mary]] that consists of two churches: an old church built in 1745 and a new church added to the sanctuary in 1999. The church was included by Pope John Paul II in the pilgrimage of [[Seven Pilgrim Churches of Rome]] during the [[Holy Year]] 2000. [[File:Santuario della Madonna del Divino Amore interno.jpg|thumb|The inside of the new church]] ==History== [[File:Santa Mar√≠a del Divino Amor.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Santa Mar√≠a del Divino Amor]] In 1295 the property belonged to the Savelli-Orsini family, who built a castle surrounded by a boundary wall and protexted by six or eight towers. The property changed hands several times and by the early eighteenth century the estate had fallen into ruin. One of the towers of a gatehouse, known as the ''Castel di Leva'', was decorated with a medieval [[fresco]], a votive image of the Madonna and Child. The painting, whose artist is unknown, portrayed the Virgin Mary sitting on a Throne and holding the child Jesus in her arms. A dove descends upon her as a symbol of the Holy Spirit.{{cite web |url=http://www.santuariodivinoamore.it/en.html |title=History of the sanctuary of our Lady of Divine Love |author=Official website |work=santuariodivinoamore.it |year=2011 |accessdate=3 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131071236/http://www.santuariodivinoamore.it/en.html |archivedate=31 January 2013 |df= }} Local shepherds who grazed their flocks nearby during the winter would often meet here to pray the Rosary.[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/96013 Morra, Mario. "Our Lady of Divine Love", Santi e Beati] In 1740, a pilgrim was attacked by angry dogs near the gatehouse and, according to the tradition, was saved through the [[intercession]] of the Blessed Virgin Mary. Seeing the image, the man invoked the Mother of God for help. Immediately the dogs calmed down and ran off into the countryside. Word spread of this occurrence and the following September the painting was moved to a nearby estate called "La Falconiana", were stood a small church dedicated to the Virgin under the title Santa Maria ad Magos (St Mary of the Magi).{{cite web |url=http://www.santuariodivinoamore.it/es.html |title=Parrocchia-Santuario Santa Maria del Divino Amore |year=2007 |author=Santuario Madonna del Divino Amore |location=Roma |access-date=21 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629070315/http://www.santuariodivinoamore.it/es.html |archivedate=29 June 2015 |df= }} On Easter Monday, April 19, 1745, the painting was returned to a new church, built near the site of the old tower. On 31 May 1750, Cardinal Carlo Rezzonico (later [[Pope Clement XIII]]) consecrated the altar in the church to Our Lady of Divine Love.{{cite book|author=Santoro, Nicholas J. |title=Mary In Our Life: Atlas of the Names and Titles of Mary, The Mother of Jesus, and Their Place in Marian Devotion |year=2011 |location=Bloomington |publisher=iUniverse |isbn=978-1-4620-4021-6 |page=46 |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=ZXWRgP-0KBkC&pg=PA46 |access-date=30 December 2015}} The church became a site of pilgrimage. With the increase of devotion from the people in the countryside, the church was entrusted to a hermit guardian, the first of which was Pasquale Francesco. After the fall of the Papal State in 1870 and the confiscation of church property, the property again falls into a period of neglect and decay, although the devotion of the faithful to Our Lady of Divine Love continues. ''Sancte Marie de Divino Amore'' (in English: ''Saint Mary of Love Divine'') is a devotional title in the [[Catholic Church]] for [[Mary, the mother of Jesus]]. The image received canonical coronation on 13 May 1883{{cn|date=April 2018}} and can now be used by the faithful when addressing Mary for intercessions under this title. In December 1932, a parish was established and Don Umberto Terenzi appointed rector and the first parish priest. In March 1942 he founded the Congregation of the [[Daughters of Our Lady of Divine Love]]. During World War II, the fresco was moved to the church of St. Ignatius. Pope [[Pius XII]] and many Romans visited the shrine to pray for the Holy Mother's intercession that the city be spared. On June 11, 1944 Pius XII went to pray before the Image of the Virgin, surrounded by an immense crowd, and bestows the title of ''Salvatrice dell'Urbe''. In 1962, the Oblate Priests were founded, who since then serve the shrine. The pilgrimages increase, especially from Whit Monday until autumn. The shrine presently on the site is new, and was inaugurated by Pope [[John Paul II]] on July 4, 1999. Pope John Paul II included the shrine in the [[Seven Pilgrim Churches of Rome]] and the pilgrim itinerary for the [[Great Jubilee|Holy Year 2000]],{{cite news|last1=Coen|first1=Emanuele| title=Nasce un percorso pedonale e ciclabile da san Paolo al Divino Amore. 15 chilometri di sentieri tra basiliche, parchi e catacombe| url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1999/06/01/nasce-un-percorso-pedonale-ciclabile-da-san.html|accessdate=30 April 2018|work=La Repubblica|date=1 June 1999| language=it}} replacing [[San Sebastiano fuori le Mura]]. Behind the chapel is a staircase that leads down to the gate tower where the miracle occurred in 1740.{{cite web|url=http://www.zenit.org/es/articles/el-padre-terenzi-impulsor-del-santuario-del-divino-amor-roma-camino-a-los-altares |title=El padre Terenzi, impulsor del Santuario del Divino Amor (Roma), camino a los altares |editor=Zenit |date=28 January 2004 |access-date=30 December 2015}} [[Pope Francis]] visited the shrine on 1 May 2018 to say the rosary, marking the start of the month dedicated to Mary. {{cite news | work = Vatican News | accessdate = 1 May 2018 | date= 1 May 2018 | url = https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2018-05/pope-francis-divino-amore-pilgrim-shrine-our-lady-divine-love.html | title = Pope Francis: pilgrim to the Shrine of Our Lady of Divine Love| first = Richard | last = Marsden}} ==Interior== The miraculous painting is enshrined above the altar. The mosaics in the [[apse]] are modern, and shows Christ in the centre, and the miracle on the left. In the crypt is the tomb of the married couple [[Luigi Beltrame Quattrocchi|Bl. Luigi (Aloysius) Beltrame Quattrocchi]] and [[Maria Corsini Beltrame Quattrocchi|Bl. Maria Corsini Beltrame Quattrocchi]]. He died in 1951, and she in 1965. After their deaths, a beatification process was started. They were beatified on 21 October 2001 by Pope John Paul II, and this was the first time that a married couple had been beatified together. Their [[translation (relic)|relics were moved]] here on 28 October 2001. The feast of Bl. Luigi and Maria Corsini Beltrame Quattrocchi is celebrated on 25 November, their wedding day. ==References== {{Commons category|Madonna del Divino Amore (Rome)}} *{{commonscat-inline|Santuario della Madonna del Divino Amore (Rome)}} {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Pietra|first=Pierluigi |title=La Madonna del Divino Amore: il suo santuario, la sua opera|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VaRPHQAACAAJ|accessdate=3 April 2013|year=1958|language=Italian}} *{{cite book|last=Garella|first=Luciano |title=Il Divino Amore a Roma: storia della costruzione|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q5RNAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=3 April 2013|year=2007|publisher=Gangemi|isbn=978-88-492-1238-9|language=Italian}} ==External links== *[http://cdm16028.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/107497 The Vatican: spirit and art of Christian Rome], a book from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on the Santuario {{DEFAULTSORT:Santuario Della Madonna Del Divino Amore}} [[Category:Roman Catholic churches in Rome]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches completed in 1745]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches completed in 1999]] [[Category:18th-century Roman Catholic church buildings]] [[Category:20th-century Roman Catholic church buildings]] [[Category:Titles of Mary]]

'''Sarah Elizabeth Titcomb''' (1841 ‚Äì April 15, 1895) was an American [[Genealogy|genealogist]] and writer.
Titcomb was born in [[Lowell, Massachusetts]]. She took interest in genealogy and was the author of ''Early New England People'' (1882).<ref>Anonymous. (1896). ''The New England Historical and Genealogical Register, 1896, Volume L''. Boston. p. 384. Republished by Heritage Books, 1998. {{ISBN|0-7884-0865-8}}</ref>
Titcomb was an advocate of what was known in the 19th century as the "[[New thought|mind cure]]".<ref>A. M. (1885). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1761990 ''The Mind-Cure'']. ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' 6 (150): 543-544.</ref><ref>Anonymous. (1886). [http://bjp.rcpsych.org/content/32/139/409 ''Mind-Cure on a Material Basis'']. ''[[British Journal of Psychiatry]]'' 32 (139): 409-411.</ref> She wrote the book ''Mind-Cure on a Material Basis'' (1885). Titcomb believed that [[disease]] could be caused and cured by [[imagination]] and the [[mind]]. According to Titcomb the success of the cure was based on the concentration of thought and not to any underlying [[theology]].<ref>Anonymous. (1884). ''Titcomb (Sarah E.) Mind-Cure on a Material Basis''. Tr√ºbner's American and Oriental Literary Record. p. 12. "The mind-cure receives an extended examination, with the conclusion that its success is due to concentration of thought, and not to the theology of the Christian scientists."</ref><ref>Anonymous. (1886). ''Mind-Cure on a Material Basis. By Sarah Elizabeth Titcomb''. ''[[Popular Science Monthly]]'' 28: 417.</ref> Because of her theological differences she received criticism from [[Mary Baker Eddy]] and advocates of [[Christian Science]].<ref>Eddy, Mary Baker. (1896). ''Miscellaneous Writings, 1883-1896''. Boston. p. 62</ref><ref>[https://journal.christianscience.com/issues/1886/3/3-12/mind-cure-on-a-material-basis "Mind-Cure on a Material Basis"]. March 1886 issue of The Christian Science Journal.</ref>
She also wrote ''Aryan Sun Myths: The Origin of Religions'' (1889), a book on [[comparative religion]] and [[solar myth]]s.<ref name= "Open Court">Anonymous. (1890). [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112045865984;view=1up;seq=285;size=175 ''Aryan Sun-Myths the Origin of Religions'']. ''[[The Open Court (journal)|The Open Court]]'' 4: 2555.</ref> Titcomb was a proponent of the [[Christ Myth theory]], according to a review of her book she held the view that [[Jesus Christ]] was a personification of a [[solar deity]].<ref name= "Open Court"/>
